<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FS_GetPhysDriveName:
```c
int32 OS_FS_GetPhysDriveName(char *PhysDriveName, const char *MountPoint)
{
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    int32                         return_code;
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(MountPoint);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(PhysDriveName);

    /* Get a reference lock, as a filesystem check could take some time. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)MountPoint, &token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token);

        if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM) != 0)
        {
            strncpy(PhysDriveName, filesys->system_mountpt, OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN - 1);
            PhysDriveName[OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN - 1] = 0;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock

         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.

    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}

explanation: Only the two listed lines in OS_FS_GetPhysDriveName invoke standard string handling behavior that can cause out-of-bounds accesses and therefore must be investigated for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. No other calls to <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) are present in the function. The other code fragments (parameter checks, object lookup, table access, flag test, token release, and return handling) do not perform string copying/reading via the C standard string functions and thus are not relevant to Rule 21.17. The macros OS_CHECK_POINTER and OS_CHECK_PATHNAME perform validation but do not guarantee the size of the caller-supplied PhysDriveName buffer; they therefore do not eliminate the need to inspect the two suspicious fragments above.
